EDVISIT^43471375^KIMBROUGH, AMELIA^05/29/59^STEELE, SHAYLYN
This patient was seen with resident, Dr. Elmore. Resident's
note was reviewed. The patient was seen and examined by me, and
I confirm the resident's findings.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: In brief, Ms. Kimbrough is a
46-year-old woman with history of hypothyroidism, anxiety,
diabetes, and nephrotic syndrome. She is also dialysis
dependent. Her last dialysis was yesterday, she developed acute
onset chest pressure with severe shortness of breath and
diaphoresis while at home. Called EMS and was brought to the
Emergency Department. The patient is unable to give a full
history and at this time secondary to her significant respiratory
distress. Please review resident's note for full details of
obtainable past medical history, social history, review of
systems, medications, and allergies.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: I confirm the physical exam is as
documented. The patient is awake in severe respiratory distress.
Pulse is 126, respirations 40, blood pressure is initially noted
at 253/129, and oximetry is 92% on facemask. Physical exam
reveals a diaphoretic woman who is breathing rapidly with
accessory muscle use, nasal flaring and tripoding. She has rales
halfway up bilaterally with inspiratory and expiratory wheezes.
Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia. Abdomen is obese but soft.
Extremity exam reveals bilateral 3+ edema up to the knees.
Rectal exam reveals trace heme-positive stool that is brown.
On route, the patient received multiple doses of sublingual
nitroglycerin as well as IV Lasix. She is known to make urine, a
Foley catheter was placed immediately. IV access was
established, and the patient received large doses of diuretics.
Was immediately started on IV nitroglycerin and a BiPAP. On
BiPAP, the patient's oxygenation was 100%.
LABORATORY DATA: Labs were obtained, which showed a hematocrit
of 36, and BUN and creatinine of 15 and 5.1. BNP was noted at
700. Cardiac enzymes: CK was 334, CK-MB 4.9, and troponin was
less than assay. However, labs were obtained within half an hour
of her symptoms starting, magnesium was low at 1.6. Urinalysis
was negative and urine HCG was negative. EKG was sinus
tachycardia without any ST or T-wave changes concerning for
rate-related ischemia. There were no prior EKGs available.
Chest x-ray showed bilateral CHF. The Nephrology fellow covering
hemodialysis was notified that the patient would need immediate
hemodialysis and this was scheduled for 6:00 a.m.
DIAGNOSIS: End-stage renal disease, hemodialysis dependent, and
CHF.
ASSESSMENT: Given the patient's constellation of symptoms, it is
likely that she had an ischemic event that caused flash pulmonary
edema and subsequent symptomatology. Given the current regimen,
in the Emergency Department, the patient gradually improved. The
respiratory rate was noted at 23. Her heart rate came down to
113 and blood pressure was well controlled on the IV
nitroglycerin noted finally at 140/77. The patient was taken to
hemodialysis at 7:45 and admitted to the hospital thereafter for
